reviewText: Well, I wish I could have enjoyed this game but at level 3 of the tutorial, game requires the use of mouse wheel in order to complete the level. Why force the use of mouse wheel? No idea and no real rationale behind it. Developers could have simply implemented the use of two keys for the same results. Or could have supported gamepad. Though luck: my computer is a laptop. Couldn't move forward in the game. Game specs don't specify that the use of mouse wheel is mandatory. Refund requested and obtained. So beware before buying this game.
voteText: 30 of 49 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game is a lot of fun and reminds me a lot of those oil and water dripper games that I used to really enjoy as a kid.  The presentation is nice and the fluid physics seem to be pretty spot on.  They react how you expect them to react and do so reliably each time which is important for physics based gameplay like this.  It seems like it would be a simple concept that would be difficult to find challenge in, but the levels do up the ante as you progress.  Very early in I was presented with a few that really had me scratching my head a bit.  But they weren't so difficult that I left the experience frustrated.\n\nMost importantly, the dev is very responsive to the community and you can tell they are very passionate about the game.  I had a small scoring issue which I posted about and got a reply within hours.  The bug was not only fixed within the week but followed up on in the comment thread by the dev to let me know.  It's a pleasure to support devs who are so active with their community and willing to fix things even when they can't replicate the bugs we're seeing.  It's a refreshing change from so many of these unfinished or bug-ridden games that release then wallow for months without updates.  Well worth a purchase if even just to support those qualities that we should be looking for in game devs.  It doesn't hurt that it's pretty fun to boot.

reviewText:
I had to play this game for about half an hour to collect what I needed for this review, I'm surprised this game is on Mixed reviews. I can say I've never owned nor played the original but I got the hang of it quite quickly. Bloop Reloaded doesn't required much of a tutorial but fulfills when required.
Pros:
- Simple & easy to play.
- Easy to use level builder.
- Nice artistic graphics.
- Fun Music.
- Steam Trading Cards.

Cons:
- Short Gameplay although the Level Builder extends it.
- Expensive for a small game.

Price:
I didn't pay full price for this game, around $1. On steam it is valued at $10... I have to say right now, never pay $10 for this game. You can usually find it on sale & even then it can be a little pricey. Personally I'd value it at $1-$2.

Overall Score:
I'd give Bloop Reloaded by 2SD a 58/100. Fun for a while when you're bored but not exactly worth a $10 investment.

reviewText:
I was supplied with this key by the developer, this however did not affect the review. All my developer sponsored reviews are positive because I review games that I like!
═══════════════════════════════════
OVERVIEW
Bloop Reloaded

This game is similar to classics like Lemmings. You guide an oject to an objective. The main difference between this game and Lemmings is that while Lemmings deals mostly with a programming aspect to guide the objects to the objective, Bloop Reloaded uses physics to guide liquids. You must create platforms to guide the liquids to the bottle, avoiding hazards and sometimes mixing to liquids to get an end product. Aside from the pre-level setup of platforms, the player can use the right mouse button to pick up and move quantities of the liquid.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/315060/

═══════════════════════════════════
PROS & CONS
Pros
The ambient music is great
Cons
The mechanics are poorly explained
The right mouse button mechanic defeats the puzzle aspect of the game
Instead of a cooldown for the right mouse button mechanic, you must hunt down and left click on floating ojects to gain more time that this ability can be active
═══════════════════════════════════
SUMMARY & FINAL RATING
This game suffers a few design flaws that make it less fun to play. Being able to pick up the liquids and move them around defeats the need to solve a puzzle. If Lemmings allowed such a function, the game would not have been as successful. The fact that this ability can be active for a certain amount of time and then be recharged hurts the gameplay. Having the skill slowly recharge would make the skill more interesting than having to switch tasks to find the skill recharge items. It plays like two distantly related minigames that are expected to be perceived as a whole game. I really like puzzle games for their need to plan out how to complete a level, but the right mouse button skill negates the need to really plan for anything.

3/10
═══════════════════════════════════
For more recommendations and reviews on our favourite up and coming quality games follow  Lot's O Giveaway's  group curations  here !

reviewText:
-Made in Unity.
-Kevin MacLeod music.
-if you press space after finishing a level it doesnt register as completed, wasting all progress done.
-Dumb mechanic of clicking random balls to recharge liquid levitation/magnet power.
-Liquid sometimes doesn't collide with the lines and goes through them, mainly because it is not polished mechanic. (happens mostly when making curves, the lines don't connect so liquids leak, countered by adding unnecessary extra lines everywhere, reason details in the comments)

-There are better liquid puzzle games on steam, do not buy this one.

Disclaimer: i have a strong bias toward hating games made in Unity. (But it is the execution that is flawed. So my points are still valid)

reviewText:
I like puzzle games in general. This one is a really cool physics based puzzle. I like the way diffrent chemical behaves. But this game suffers with a bad UI design. There is no way to restart a level you will have to quit the game to main menu and the select the desired level.
it is still a solid puzzle game which doesn't hold your hand (at all). After 2-3 basic levels there is no info or help. You will have to figure out everything on your own. Sometimes you will feel lost, and it may frustrate you.

In my opinion it is a flawed gem, which fulfils my hunger for puzzle.
